#Text=Kineubenae

#Text=Chief Kineubenae ( also recorded as Golden Eagle , Quinipeno , Quenebenaw , etc. ) ( fl. 1797 – 1812 ) , was a principal chief of the Mississauga Ojibwa , located on the north shore of Lake Ontario .
#Text=His name Giniw-bine in the Anishinaabe language means " golden eagle[-like partridge ] " .
#Text=He was a member of the Nigig- doodem ( Otter Clan ) .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Born in the mid-18th century , Kineubenae grew up in the last decades of Ojibwa domination of present-day southern Ontario .
#Text=Two generations earlier his ancestors had swept southward from the Mississagi River of the Georgian Bay and by 1700 had expelled the Iroquois .
#Text=For the next 75 years Mississaugas alone would occupy the north shore of Lake Ontario .
#Text=But all changed with the outbreak of the American revolution .
#Text=Kineubenae soon witnessed the arrival in his homeland of thousands of white and Iroquois refugees .
#Text=Suddenly the Mississaugas were obliged to cede their territory at the western end of the lake in order to provide land for the newcomers .

#Text=Retaining for themselves the " Mississauga Tract , " an area lying between Burlington Bay ( Hamilton Harbour ) and the Credit River , they agreed in 1784 to the surrenders on the understanding , in Kineubenae ’s later words , that " the Farmers would help us , " and that the Indians could " encamp and fish where we pleased . "
#Text=In fact – as the chief himself complained in 1805 – the promises were not kept .
#Text=Instead of assisting the Indians , the farmers " when we encamp on the Land . . . drove us off and shoot our dogs and never give us any assistance as was promised to our old Chiefs . "
#Text=Meanwhile , the Mississaugas were fast disappearing .
#Text=Close contact with Europeans had brought to the villages diseases such as smallpox and tuberculosis , against which they had no natural immunity .
#Text=Over the period from 1787 to 1798 the Mississaugas at the western end of Lake Ontario declined from more than 500 to approximately 350 .
#Text=As the principal chief of the Mississaugas on Twelve Mile ( Bronte ) Creek , Kineubenae frequently spoke for the Mississaugas in the early 19th century .
#Text=In 1805 , for example , he negotiated with the British over the proposed sale of the " Mississauga Tract . "
#Text=The surviving minutes of the conference reveal that Kineubenae was a shrewd bargainer .

#Text=On the first day he firmly opposed the surrender of more land , for , as he told William Claus , deputy superintendent general of Indian affairs in Upper Canada , " the young Men & Women have found fault with so much having been sold before : it is true we are poor , & the Women say we will be worse , if we part with any more . "
#Text=Only after the British applied pressure on the second day did he comply .

#Text=Then , in return for ceding the entire lakefront of the tract ( the Indians retained the interior section until 1818 ) , Kineubenae extracted a promise from the British that the Mississaugas would keep the river mouths and their rights to the fisheries there .
#Text=Within a year , however , Kineubenae was protesting against the settlers ’ encroachments on the fisheries .
#Text=In 1806 he complained about the white man who had taken over his cornfield at Bronte Creek and then destroyed it , as well as that of a poor Indian widow who had four children to support .
#Text=The same white settler , Kineubenae reported , was building a weir to catch salmon on their way upstream to spawn .

#Text=In addition , a white squatter at the Credit River had so disturbed the waters " by washing with sope and other dirt , that the fish refuse coming into the River as usual , by which our families are in great distress for want of food . "
#Text=Death
#Text=By 1812
#Text=Kineubenae was becoming extremely weak and on his own admission " getting too old to walk . "

#Text=For nearly two decades he had led his people and during this time most of their lands had been taken , the fish and game populations had declined drastically , and their own numbers had been severely reduced .
#Text=Then the war between the British and the Americans had extended to the north shore of Lake Ontario .
#Text=It was at this point that Kineubenae , in order to inspire his band with an example of the strength of their traditions , fasted and obtained " warrior ’s medicine . "
#Text=A group of Mississaugas gathered by a river mouth at the western end of Lake Ontario .

#Text=As the warriors squatted around him the old chief , Kineubenae , slowly began to tell of the fast in which , through the grace of unseen spirit powers , he had obtained protection against arrows , tomahawks , and even bullets .
#Text=And he would demonstrate this gift .
#Text=He took a tin kettle and , with some difficulty on account of his age , walked a short distance away from the circle .
#Text=As soon as he raised the kettle up before his face a warrior was to fire , and Kineubenae would collect the bullet in the kettle .
#Text=The marksman , like the others , believed in Kineubenae ’s " medicine " and he fired .
#Text=The chief instantly fell .
#Text=The band , to their horror , found that " the lead went into his head and [ had ] killed him on the spot . "
#Text=That one bullet did more than kill a respected leader ; it shook the faith of many Mississaugas in their traditional way of life .
#Text=Kineubenae 's death , decades later , would facilitate the work of Peter Jones in converting the demoralized Mississaugas to Christianity .
